title: 104_s373
content:
The Act may be cited as the "State Regulation and Management of Solid Waste Act of 1995". The Solid Waste Disposal Act is amended to require each state to develop a program for managing solid waste by 2015, allowing states to restrict the importation of waste for management purposes, and providing financial and technical assistance. The Solid Waste Disposal Act is amended to require states to develop waste management programs by 2015, including developing alternatives to land disposal methods due to landfill closures. Financial and technical assistance will be provided for waste reduction and proper disposal practices. The transportation of solid waste long distances across the country, sometimes in the same vehicles as consumer goods, is harmful to public health. Measures should be taken to protect public health when goods are transported alongside solid waste. SEC. 102. OBJECTIVES AND NATIONAL POLICY. Section 1003(a) of the Solid Waste Disposal Act is amended to ensure that each State has a program for managing solid waste and providing assistance for the development of solid waste management plans. This includes promoting improved techniques for solid waste management, collection, separation, recovery, and environmentally safe disposal. The Solid Waste Disposal Act is amended to promote the use of regional and interstate agreements for efficient and environmentally friendly solid waste management practices, as well as the development of markets for recycled products and recovered resources. SEC. 103. DEFINITIONS. Section 1004 of the Solid Waste Disposal Act is amended to define the term 'manifest' for identifying waste during transportation and to include recycling and resource recovery in various paragraphs. The Solid Waste Disposal Act is amended to include a definition of 'manifest' for waste transportation and to specify the types of refuse collected from the general public. The Solid Waste Disposal Act is amended to include definitions for 'recycling', 'State of final destination', and 'State of origin' related to solid waste management. TITLE II--STATE SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT PLANS

SEC. 201. OBJECTIVES OF SUBTITLE D.

Amendment to Section 4001 of the Solid Waste Disposal Act to specify the objectives of the subtitle. The objectives of this subtitle are to reduce solid waste generation, promote resource conservation, and facilitate recycling through federal guidelines and cooperation among different levels of government and private entities. The curr_chunk focuses on encouraging states to enter agreements for efficient solid waste management and overseeing the implementation of waste management plans. SEC. 202. STATE SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT PLANS. The focus is on encouraging states to enter agreements for efficient solid waste management and overseeing the implementation of waste management plans. The amendment to Section 4003 of the Solid Waste Disposal Act requires each State Solid Waste Management Plan to identify and manage solid waste quantities, types, sources, and characteristics expected over the next 20 years. The State Solid Waste Management Plan must ensure environmentally sound management capacity for solid waste over the next 20 years, taking into account existing waste management agreements. The State Solid Waste Management Plan must include annual certification to the Administrator on meeting objectives, issuing permits for waste capacity, and approving sites for waste management facilities. All facilities in the State must comply with applicable regulations. The State Solid Waste Management Plan requires all solid waste management facilities in the State to register with the State, providing owner and operator details, facility address, and type of waste management used. The State Solid Waste Management Plan includes provisions for managing waste quantities, types, and sources at facilities. It also outlines technical and financial assistance for local communities and specifies conditions for accepting waste from other states. Upon the expiration of 180 days after the approval of a State's Solid Waste Management Plan or on the date a State plan becomes effective, it will be illegal to manage, transport, or accept solid waste without authorization as outlined in the approved plan. Each State must submit their plan within 4 years of this requirement. Each State must submit a plan for solid waste management to the Administrator for approval, meeting specific requirements and furthering the objectives of the Solid Waste Disposal Act. The Administrator will review each State's certification to determine compliance with the Solid Waste Disposal Act. If revisions are needed, approval of the plan will be withheld after a public hearing. If the Administrator does not act on a State plan within 18 months, it will be considered approved. After a State plan is submitted for approval, it will go into effect 18 months later, subject to review and possible revision by the Administrator. TITLE III--INTERSTATE TRANSPORT OF WASTE

SEC. 301. AUTHORITY OF STATES TO CONTROL INTERSTATE SHIPMENT OF SOLID WASTE.

Subtitle D of the Solid Waste Disposal Act is amended by adding a new section, "SEC. 4011. AUTHORITY TO RESTRICT INTERSTATE TRANSPORT OF SOLID WASTE." SEC. 4011 grants states the authority to restrict the interstate transport of solid waste after approval of a Solid Waste Management Plan. States can prohibit or restrict the import of solid waste for management purposes, with limitations outlined in section 4003(a)(12). SEC. 4012 addresses fees related to solid waste management. SEC. 4012 allows states to levy fees on solid waste based on origin, with at least 50% of revenues allocated to local governments for waste management purposes. TITLE IV--FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE

SEC. 401. FEDERAL ASSISTANCE.

Amends the Solid Waste Disposal Act to authorize $25,000,000 annually for grants to States for recycling, resource recovery, and conservation activities.

SEC. 402. RURAL COMMUNITIES ASSISTANCE. SEC. 402. RURAL COMMUNITIES ASSISTANCE. Amends the Solid Waste Disposal Act to authorize $50,000,000 for each of fiscal years 1996, 1997, and 1998 for rural communities assistance.
